title: Powerlifting and Training
content: Mark and Chris Bell discuss their love of powerlifting, their unbelievable personal records, and what prompted the making of their now iconic film, Bigger, Stronger, Faster.

title: Steroid Use
content: Mark and Chris Bell also very openly discuss steroid use, their tragic family history with addiction, and their dedication to having a positive impact on others in fitness and life.

title: Lifting weights
content: Lifting weights: the importance of challenging yourself, how to avoid injury, monitoring progress, and staying motivated [1:02:30]; Chris on how changing his diet changed his performance and life [1:09:15]; Best resources for those wanting to get started lifting weights effectively and safely [1:14:00]; Teaching kids strength training early in life, the negative impact of sitting and how we can minimize it [1:18:30]; Benefits of bodybuilding, Mark’s prep for his first competition, and the role of the ketogenic diet [1:27:15];

title: Steroid controversy
content: The impact of Bigger, Stronger, Faster, how it got made, and how it challenged Peter’s set of beliefs regarding steroids [4:45]; The steroid controversy: Mark’s use of them and Peter’s perspective [1:42:15];

title: Testosterone
content: Testosterone: Peter’s approach to improving it in patients, and the impact of sleep, cortisol, and statins on production [1:51:00];

title: Mark and Chris Bell's Powerlifting Journey
content: In this episode, Mark and Chris Bell discuss their love of powerlifting, their unbelievable personal records, and what prompted the making of their now iconic film, Bigger, Stronger, Faster. They also very openly discuss steroid use, their tragic family history with addiction, the many inspirations that lead to their multifaceted success, and their dedication to having a positive impact on others in fitness and more

title: The Impact of Stress on Physical and Emotional Health
content: #51 rebroadcast - The impact of stress on our physical and emotional health | Robert Sapolsky, Ph.D.

title: Optimizing Brain Health and Alzheimer's Prevention
content: #251 - AMA #46: Optimizing brain health: Alzheimer's disease risk factors, APOE, prevention strategies, and more

title: Powerlifting and Personal Records
content: Mark and Chris Bell discuss powerlifting, their personal records, and the importance of challenging yourself while lifting weights.

title: Avoiding Injury and Staying Motivated
content: The importance of avoiding injury, monitoring progress, and staying motivated while lifting weights is discussed.

title: Teaching Kids Strength Training and Minimizing Sitting
content: The benefits of teaching kids strength training early in life and minimizing the negative impact of sitting are discussed.

title: The Role of Steroids in Fitness
content: Mark's use of steroids and Peter's perspective on their use in fitness are discussed.

title: Improving Testosterone Production
content: Peter's approach to improving testosterone production in patients is discussed, including the impact of sleep, cortisol, and statins.

title: The impact of Bigger, Stronger, Faster
content: Peter revisited his set of beliefs regarding steroids after watching the documentary Bigger, Stronger, Faster. He always assumed steroids must be terrible for you and dangerous. After watching the documentary, Peter describes his realization as follows: “It was an opinion that had been passed down and passed down but I hadn’t actually submitted myself to the discomfort of thought”.

title: What lead up to the making of Bigger, Stronger, Faster
content: Chris saw the documentary Bowling for Columbine and decided he wanted to make a documentary on steroid use modeled after Bowling for Columbine. Once they started working on it, the editors and producers realized that the Bell brothers (Mark, Chris, and Mike) were the ones who needed to be filmed and they decided to focus on the Bell family. Mark and Mike were both on steroids, but Chris wasn’t but he was conflicted about whether he should or not.

title: Chris’s personal story of addiction and how he’s using his experience to help others
content: Chris’s dad recognized that he was struggling with addiction and called him out. This caused Chris to break down in tears, “worst feeling you could possibly have is that you let your father down”. Chris is now using his experience to help others.

title: The Turning Point
content: Mark got a frantic call from Chris’s girlfriend that Chris was passed out and wouldn’t wake up. Convinced Chris to fly to Sacramento and be with the family. Sent him to detox (zero contact for 3-4 days). Rehab for 60-70 days. Best thing they did as a family is they had an intervention and Chris revealed, “I feel alone”. They made the point to surround him with family, his parents playing a huge role. Family support is what made (and is making) the difference.

title: Helping Others
content: Chris feels like he has an ability to inspire people to take initiative in their lives, to get involved with something and go for it. He stresses the importance of surrounding yourself with a support group. Chris’s goal is to simply help people lead a healthier lifestyle, physically and mentally. Mark and Chris say their first prescription for everyone who is struggling is simply to get up and start moving, even if it’s just a 10-minute walk, just start.

title: Importance of Sharing Your Struggle
content: Sharing your struggle is helpful to you, but it can have an amazing impact on others because feeling alone, as Chris did, can lead people to dark places. Referring to the message spread by the late, David Foster Wallace, Peter says, “every single one of us is only experiencing the world from our own vantage point, I only know what’s in our head, we only know what we see and it’s so easy to think you are alone”. Peter suspects that their authenticity and willingness to share their struggle helps convey their good intentions (as opposed to many of the inauthentic figures in the fitness industry).

title: Stop Comparing Yourself to Others
content: It’s easy to judge someone else when you don’t know where they started. Everyone has a different starting point which makes an enormous difference on where they currently stand. Peter says, “don’t judge a man by where he stands. . . judge him by how far he’s traveled to get there”. The bottom line is you should only look at your own progress, not other’s endpoints.

title: Early Life and Inspiration
content: Mark says, “We had the ability to dream because our dad provided and mom provided that for us. That’s all we had to worry about as kids were to dream big. That’s it.” Huge fans of pro wrestling (WWE). The day that changed their life: Hulk Hogan beat the Iron Sheik January 23, 1984, and from that point on all they could imagine for their future was being inside the wrestling ring. Dad worked for IBM and gave his everything to the company for 20 years.

title: How they got started lifting weights
content: They first witnessed the raw strength of their older brother “Mad Dog” (Mike) who was squatting 400 lbs at age 16. In 10th grade, Chris had bone spurs in his knees and needed surgery. His chiropractor/strength coach said you need to learn to squat to help your knees (counterintuitive to Chris). Started with broomstick learning to squat properly. Slowly moved up in weight and 6 months later squatting 315 lbs for 8 reps. Ended up squatting over 500 lbs while still in high school. Chris was squatting 675 by 19 years old. When Mark was about 13 years old, their cousin (who was about 19) came over and challenged Mark to a “bench off”. Up until that point, Mark had never really “maxed out” so was unsure how much he could lift. They kept adding weight, and his cousin fails at 205 lbs, but Mark got 240-250 lbs at age 13! It’s in their genes: their mom benched 135 lbs never having benched in her life.

title: Steroid use in high school
content: Steroid use at their high school was pretty rampant. Chris, who was against steroids back in the day, would wear a weightlifting belt with “Roids Suck” written across it. This would piss people off since most of them were on steroids, yet Chris was still stronger than them. Chris laughs about the irony that he made a movie later in life suggesting that maybe steroids are not all that bad for you.

title: Olympic lifting vs. Powerlifting
content: Olympic lifting: 2 lifts, the snatch, and the clean and jerk. 3 attempts at each lift. the highest score of each lift is taken and summed together to get your total score. Powerlifting: Consists of 3 lifts, squat, bench, deadlift in that order. 3 attempts at each lift. Sum up best lift of each for a total score. Powerlifting is hard because it’s hard to have leverage on each of those lifts. Olympic lifting is more about being more mobile and athletic around the weight. Mark and Chris practiced powerlifting more so than Olympic lifting.

title: Personal records in powerlifting
content: Peter used powerlifting for boxing in high school. Weighing about 160 lbs. Bench = 275 lbs. Squat = 495 lbs. Deadlift = 505 lbs. Using powerlifting gear (which gives you an advantage): Squat = 1080 lbs. Bench = 854 lbs. Deadlift = 766 lbs. Raw (without any gear or knee wraps): Squat = 700 lbs. Bench = 578 lbs. Deadlift = 715 lbs. Chris’s PRs: Squat = 675 lbs (assisted with gear).

title: Importance of Challenging Yourself and Avoiding Injury
content: Peter and Mark discuss the importance of challenging yourself while avoiding injury when lifting weights. Peter's #1 rule is to not get hurt, while Mark's rule is to challenge yourself first and avoid injury second. They also discuss the importance of warming up to avoid injury.

title: Challenging Yourself to Make Progress and Staying Motivated
content: Mark emphasizes the importance of making progress and setting attainable goals to stay motivated. He suggests trying new things and different rep ranges to keep challenging yourself. He also believes that progress is necessary for happiness.

title: The Impact of Diet on Performance and Life
content: Chris shares how changing his diet to a ketogenic/carnivore diet helped him lose weight and improve his performance. He also regrets not optimizing his training along with his diet earlier in his life.

title: Best Resources for Effective and Safe Weightlifting
content: Peter recommends Mark Rippetoe's Starting Strength book and YouTube channel for those needing instruction for strength training. Mark's YouTube channel, Mark Bell - Sling Shot, has over 3,000 videos, including instructional videos.

title: CrossFit
content: Mark believes CrossFit is a great place to start. Mark says “There has never in the history of the world has been a better fitness program than what Crossfit puts out. Nobody spends more time and more money on what they put together.”

title: Powerlifting
content: Powerlifting will help improve your fitness in many different sports. By powerlifting, you will not only learn valuable mechanics but you’ll also improve in your sport. Teaching kids strength training early in life, the negative impact of sitting and how we can minimize it [1:18:30]. “I would love it if each of my kids at least spends some time powerlifting because whatever you go to do later in life you will have correctly learned the mechanics of the most important movements in the human body,” says Peter. Jeff Martin (San Diego) has a program for kids called The Brand X Method. Mark did a seminar there and was blown away with how the kids were able to move. Their form on everything was impeccable. Adults are harder to teach, less flexible, tighter in the hips, mental blocks due to a bad experience with lifting in the past. Peter says his 4-year-old boy (not in school yet so doesn’t sit) and his squat form is great, but his daughter who is now 10 years and used to have great form but now it is horrible.

title: Bodybuilding
content: Benefits of bodybuilding, Mark’s prep for his first competition, and the role of the ketogenic diet [1:27:15]. You can see rapid changes with bodybuilding. Mark believes the discipline you develop from sticking to a bodybuilding regimen is a powerful trait to have in your toolbox. Jay Cutler is the example of discipline. 4 time Mr. Olympia champion. Mark transitions from powerlifting to bodybuilding at age 41. He was already in the process of adjusting his diet to lose fat and was convinced by Hany Rambod (nutritionist for Phil Heath) on his Power Project podcast to go ahead and sign up for his first bodybuilding competition. NOTE: Since this recording, Mark has already competed and won his first ever bodybuilding competition. From Mark’s YouTube channel: BEFORE AND AFTER BODYBUILDING TRANSFORMATION ft. Hany Rambod. Bodybuilding diet: Mark’s diet for his upcoming competition. 7 meals per day. 350 g protein (50 g protein per meal). 150 g carbs. 65 g fat. Mark points out that this might look like a lot but the average person eats 15 times per day (due to all the snacking).

title: Training and Protein Intake
content: According to Chris, increasing protein intake can lead to major changes in muscle growth. He suggests consuming 1.7 grams of protein per kilogram of body weight at every meal to get muscular hypertrophy.

title: Mark's Bodybuilding Journey
content: Mark started at 245 lbs and ended at 215 lbs for the competition. He worked with Hany Rambod for nutrition, Charles Glass for posing, and Mike O'Hearn for training. His macros were 2600 total calories with 54% protein, 23% carbs, and 23% fat.

title: Ketogenic Diet in Bodybuilding
content: Mark found the ketogenic diet helpful in controlling his hunger and cravings. While it may not play a significant role for pro bodybuilders, it could help former overweight individuals like Mark to tighten up and gain mental freedom. It's important to change up the regimen to avoid becoming less effective.

title: Steroid Controversy
content: Mark, who is currently using steroids, explains that they allow people to gain more weight and strength, but they only work to a certain level. Steroids alone do not produce the type of results seen in professional bodybuilders. Steroids are still very much a part of the sport.

title: Anabolic Steroids
content: Peter spent five years learning about anabolic steroids and concluded that there is little evidence of harm when used within physiologic levels. The problem arises when people abuse them and don’t understand how to use them properly or within physiologic levels. Chris points out that steroids may have caused an injury when he tore his tricep and thinks he was lifting too heavy because while his muscles were capable, his tendons weren’t capable of handling the load.

title: Testosterone
content: Peter's approach to improving testosterone in patients is to resolve insulin resistance and preserve muscle mass. To diagnose low testosterone, Peter looks at free testosterone that is one or two standard deviations below the mean and symptoms such as trouble maintaining muscle mass, insulin resistance, and low libido. If free testosterone is low because testosterone is low, Peter tries to figure out why. There are nine steps in understanding someone’s testosterone and free testosterone level and we can actually impact every single one of those steps pharmacologically. Sleep deprivation is the number one diagnosis for the lack of brain signal to make more testosterone despite the fact that testosterone is low. Hypercortisolemia and statins can also inhibit testosterone production.

title: Statins and Testosterone Production
content: The body prioritizes cholesterol for forming cellular membranes and hormone production, but at the levels most people take statins, it does not inhibit endogenous testosterone production.

title: Upcoming Nutrition Documentary
content: The documentary will be loosely based on the world of nutrition and will likely include Mark’s journey into bodybuilding at age 41. They are planning for the film to be out next year.

title: Parting Advice from Mark
content: Mark encourages everyone to start walking for at least 10 minutes a day, preferably after lunch or dinner, to clear their minds and improve their health.

title: Kratom and Mind Bullet
content: Chris made a film called A Leaf of Faith that explores the kratom plant and its purported benefits including getting people off opioids and relieving pain. Mark and Chris developed a product using kratom called Mind Bullet, which they use as a pain reliever, pre-workout, and for euphoria.

title: Mark and Chris' Resources
content: Mark and Chris have various resources, including Mark's YouTube channel, Mark Bell's Power Project podcast, and Super Training Gym in Sacramento. Chris can be found on Instagram and Twitter, while Mark can be found on Instagram, Twitter, and his website.
